content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple tissue sections on a glass slide. There are approximately 8-9 discrete, ovoid, and intensely basophilic (purple) tissue fragments, which are characteristic of lymph nodes. They are of varying sizes and some appear fragmented. A larger, more irregular piece of tissue is present in the center. The background is white with some surrounding pinkish tissue and adipose (fat) tissue. My first impression is that this slide contains multiple lymph nodes submitted for histopathological evaluation, likely for cancer staging.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, my primary task here is to meticulously examine each lymph node for the presence of metastatic tumor cells. I would zoom into this specific area because it is located at the periphery of a lymph node (the second one from the top on the right). The interface between the lymph node parenchyma and the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue is a critical location to assess. This is where metastatic cells often first arrive (in the subcapsular sinus) and where extranodal extension (tumor breaking through the lymph node capsule into the fat) can be identified, which is an important prognostic factor. The texture in this region on the low-power view might also appear irregular, prompting a closer look. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the largest and most central tissue fragment on the slide. It's a logical starting point for a systematic review. Its larger size and less regular shape compared to the others might indicate something of interest, such as extensive tumor involvement or matting of nodes, making it a high-priority area to investigate first for signs of metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I zoomed into this specific area because it's located within the largest and most irregularly shaped lymph node, which is inherently more suspicious for metastatic involvement. The zoom target is at the periphery of the main lymphoid aggregate, where the dense purple lymphoid tissue interfaces with the surrounding paler, pinker tissue. This subcapsular/sinusoidal region is the first place metastatic cells often deposit. The contour in this area also appears irregular on low power, suggesting possible infiltration, which requires high-power examination for confirmation. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to evaluate every lymph node for the presence of metastatic carcinoma. I would systematically examine each piece of tissue on the slide. The green box indicates the start of this systematic review, focusing on one of the lymph nodes (the one at the 3 o'clock position). Zooming in is essential to assess the cellular architecture, particularly the subcapsular sinus and the parenchyma, for any atypical epithelial cells that would signify metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my standard procedure for a cancer staging case is to systematically examine every lymph node provided. The green box is placed on the lymph node at the 9 o'clock position. I am zooming in on this node as part of my routine, sequential review to assess its architecture and cellular composition, specifically looking for any metastatic tumor deposits. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the task is to examine every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The standard workflow involves a systematic, piece-by-piece evaluation of all tissue on the slide. The highlighted area covers one of these lymph nodes (the second one from the top on the left side). I would zoom into this area as part of my routine, systematic screening process to assess its architecture and cytology at higher magnification, specifically looking for tumor cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would systematically examine each lymph node present on the slide. The zoomed-in area corresponds to the lymph node at the 12 o'clock position. I am zooming in to assess its architecture, look for the presence of subcapsular sinuses, germinal centers, and most importantly, to screen for any atypical cell clusters or glandular structures that would be indicative of metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. A systematic review of every piece of tissue on the slide is crucial for accurate cancer staging. The green box is focused on one of the smaller lymph node sections at the bottom of the slide. I am zooming into this area as part of a methodical, piece-by-piece examination to assess its architecture and cellular composition at high power. This is necessary to definitively identify or exclude the presence of metastatic tumor cells, which may not be apparent at low magnification. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my protocol is to examine every piece of tissue on the slide. The green box is placed over one of the lymph node sections located in the bottom-left quadrant of the slide. I am zooming into this specific area to perform a high-power examination to screen for the presence of metastatic carcinoma cells, which are often found first in the subcapsular sinus, located at the periphery of the node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see the interface between lymphoid tissue and adipose tissue. The upper portion of the image is composed of a dense, monotonous population of small, dark, round cells consistent with lymphocytes. The lower portion consists of mature adipocytes (fat cells). The most striking feature is that the lymphoid tissue appears to be infiltrating into the surrounding adipose tissue, breaking through the normal capsule boundary. This represents extranodal extension. However, in this specific field, the infiltrating cells appear to be lymphocytes rather than malignant epithelial cells (adenocarcinoma). I do not see the characteristic glandular structures, large pleomorphic nuclei, or prominent nucleoli of metastatic colorectal cancer. My impression is that this view shows extranodal extension of lymphoid tissue, but not definitive metastasis. I would need to carefully examine the rest of this lymph node and all other nodes on the slide to search for unequivocal evidence of metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the edge of a lymph node. The tissue is composed of a dense, monotonous sheet of small, dark cells, which are lymphocytes. On the right side, there is a fibrous capsule and adjacent perinodal adipose tissue (fat). In this specific field of view, I do not see any atypical glandular structures or clusters of malignant cells within the lymphoid tissue or the subcapsular sinus. My impression of this particular area is that of a benign (negative for metastasis) lymph node, but the entire node must be scanned to make a definitive diagnosis.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I can see a dense sheet of lymphocytes, which is the native lymphoid tissue of the node. Infiltrating this lymphoid tissue and the surrounding fibroconnective tissue are nests and irregular, back-to-back glands of atypical epithelial cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and exhibit nuclear pleomorphism, hyperchromasia, and irregular nuclear contours. This morphology is characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a cross-section of a lymph node. The tissue is densely populated by a monotonous population of small, dark-staining lymphocytes, consistent with normal or reactive lymphoid tissue. The fibrous capsule is visible on the right, along with some perinodal connective tissue. I am carefully scanning for clusters of larger cells with irregular nuclei, more abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, or gland formation, which would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. In this specific field of view, I do not see any evidence of malignant cells. My impression is that this portion of the lymph node is benign/reactive and negative for metastasis, but the entire node must be scrutinized.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a section of a lymph node. The tissue is composed predominantly of dense aggregates of small, dark-staining lymphocytes, which are organized into lymphoid follicles. The overall architecture appears preserved. I do not see any atypical glandular structures, nests of malignant epithelial cells, or large pleomorphic cells that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field of view is that it shows a reactive or benign lymph node, with no evidence of metastasis.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in area shows a high-magnification view of the periphery of the lymph node. It is composed of a dense, monotonous population of small, round cells with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm, which are characteristic of lymphocytes. A thin, pink fibrous capsule is visible at the edge of the lymphoid tissue. There are no signs of metastatic carcinoma, such as atypical glands, large pleomorphic cells, or clusters of malignant epithelial cells. My impression of this specific field of view is that it shows a portion of a benign (negative for metastasis) lymph node.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see part of a lymph node and adjacent perinodal connective/adipose tissue. The normal lymphoid tissue (dense, dark purple lymphocytes) is being infiltrated and partially replaced by malignant glandular structures. These glands are composed of atypical epithelial cells with enlarged, hyperchromatic nuclei and eosinophilic cytoplasm, characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The high-magnification view shows a cross-section of a lymph node. The majority of the tissue consists of a dense, monotonous population of small, dark-staining lymphocytes, which is the normal cellular component of a lymph node. The overall architecture with lymphoid follicles appears preserved. I do not see any atypical glandular formations, large pleomorphic cells with prominent nucleoli, or extensive necrosis that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field is that it shows a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for metastasis. I would proceed to scan the rest of this node and all other nodes on the slide.
This is ROI 9 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a portion of a lymph node. There is dense lymphoid tissue composed of small, dark, round lymphocytes. This is adjacent to perinodal adipose tissue (fat cells) and some fibrous connective tissue. I can also see some blood vessels, a few of which show congestion with red blood cells. After careful examination of the interface between the lymphoid tissue and the surrounding fat (the subcapsular region), I do not see any atypical glandular structures, nests of malignant cells, or single signet ring cells that would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this portion of the lymph node is negative for metastasis.
